articles.headline: War Is Exploding Anew in Ukraine; Rebels Vow More
articles.snippet: Evidence is increasing that Russian troops and Russian equipment have been pouring into eastern Ukraine again.
articles.abstract: Evidence is increasing that Russian troops and Russian equipment have been pouring into eastern Ukraine again.
articles.lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Unexpectedly, at the height of the Ukrainian winter, war has exploded anew on a half-dozen battered fronts across eastern Ukraine, accompanied by increasing evidence that Russian troops and Russian equipment have been pouring into the region again.
articles.byline: By Rick Lyman and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: New Saudi King and U.S. Face Crucial Point in the Relationship
articles.snippet: Saudi Arabia’s new king, Salman, inherits both the policies put in place by the more assertive brother he is succeeding and the conflicts that in recent years have characterized relations with Washington.
articles.abstract: Saudi Arabia’s new king, Salman, inherits both the policies put in place by the more assertive brother he is succeeding and the conflicts that in recent years have characterized relations with Washington.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Almost a decade ago, an Arab diplomat famously likened the relationship between the United States and Saudi Arabia to a Catholic marriage “where you can have no divorce.”
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Rod Nordland and Neil MacFarquhar

articles.headline: In Stately Old Charleston, the New Buildings on the Block Are Struggling to Fit In
articles.snippet: Accustomed to basing its identity on its grand old buildings, the South Carolina city now finds it almost impossible to agree on how to build new ones as its economy and its population grow.
articles.abstract: Accustomed to basing its identity on its grand old buildings, the South Carolina city now finds it almost impossible to agree on how to build new ones as its economy and its population grow.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHARLESTON, S.C. — The elegant buildings from different eras strut across Charleston’s downtown neighborhoods like notes on a major scale: the Gothic churches, the Greek Revival storefronts, the homes in vivid pastels exuding Queen Anne grace, Georgian symmetry and Italianate grandeur.

articles.headline: Growing Scrutiny for an Allergy Trigger Used in Personal Care Products
articles.snippet: While some consumer products companies are removing the chemical, methylisothiazolinone, others are adding it to offerings including mouthwash.
articles.abstract: While some consumer products companies are removing the chemical, methylisothiazolinone, others are adding it to offerings including mouthwash.
articles.lead_paragraph: Because she has an eczema condition, Michelle Kirn intently reads ingredient labels on baby wipes, soaps and other household items to avoid allergic reactions that she says were caused by a commonly used preservative.

articles.headline: Justices to Hear Case Over Drugs Used in Executions
articles.snippet: The Supreme Court agreed to rule on three Oklahoma inmates’ contention that a new chemical combination poses a significant risk of terrible suffering.
articles.abstract: The Supreme Court agreed to rule on three Oklahoma inmates’ contention that a new chemical combination poses a significant risk of terrible suffering.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday agreed to decide a case on the constitutionality of the new combinations of drugs that some states are using to execute prisoners and that critics say cause intense suffering.
articles.byline: By Adam Liptak and Erik Eckholm

articles.headline: U.S. Attorney Preet Bharara Challenges Insider Trading Ruling
articles.snippet: Federal prosecutors are mounting a challenge to an appellate court’s verdict in an effort to reverse it, or at least narrow it.
articles.abstract: Federal prosecutors are mounting a challenge to an appellate court’s verdict in an effort to reverse it, or at least narrow it.
articles.lead_paragraph: When an appeals court overturned the convictions of two hedge fund managers last month, the ruling reverberated throughout the legal world and rewrote the government’s insider trading playbook.
articles.byline: By Matthew Goldstein and Ben Protess

articles.headline: A Gay Couple Awaits the Justices’ Decision
articles.snippet: Couples have had to navigate byzantine laws as same-sex marriage rights have progressed state by state. A Supreme Court ruling may change everything.
articles.abstract: Couples have had to navigate byzantine laws as same-sex marriage rights have progressed state by state. A Supreme Court ruling may change everything.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — It may have been a coincidence that the United States Supreme Court announced its intent to hear another same-sex marriage case the same week as the holiday honoring Martin Luther King’s Birthday, but it was hard not to notice the connection. The gay marriage question is one that has civil rights at its center, after all.

articles.headline: For SkyMall, It All Seemed So Cool at Six Miles High
articles.snippet: With its kitsch appeal, SkyMall became a kind of cultural reference point, a one-word inside joke that everyone could share.
articles.abstract: With its kitsch appeal, SkyMall became a kind of cultural reference point, a one-word inside joke that everyone could share.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, it was something of a ritual. You had made it through airport security, survived the lengthy delays and even crammed your carry-on into an overhead bin. Then you could settle in, buckle up and reach into the seat-back pocket in front of you. There, pressed up against the motion-sickness bag or the laminated emergency instruction card, you would find the latest edition of SkyMall.

articles.headline: Meant to Keep Malaria Out, Mosquito Nets Are Used to Haul Fish In
articles.snippet: The nets, with holes smaller than mosquitoes, trap much more than traditional fishing nets do and could wipe out stressed fish populations in Africa.
articles.abstract: The nets, with holes smaller than mosquitoes, trap much more than traditional fishing nets do and could wipe out stressed fish populations in Africa.
articles.lead_paragraph: BANGWEULU WETLANDS, Zambia — Out here on the endless swamps, a harsh truth has been passed down from generation to generation: There is no fear but the fear of hunger.

articles.headline: Obscure Law Is Getting Its Sexy On
articles.snippet: Lenders find a rarely invoked law to be a potent legal weapon in bankruptcies.
articles.abstract: Lenders find a rarely invoked law to be a potent legal weapon in bankruptcies.
articles.lead_paragraph: When some bondholders bought debt in casinos operated by Caesars Entertainment, they didn’t think they were gambling. Instead, they were relying on the guarantees of the parent company that it would stand behind the debt payments even if something went wrong.

articles.headline: In Vino Veritas. In Napa, Deceit.
articles.snippet: Jeffry Hill is accused of passing off wine from surrounding counties as a Napa Valley product and of stealing the grapes of another winery. His company has filed for bankruptcy and is being shut.
articles.abstract: Jeffry Hill is accused of passing off wine from surrounding counties as a Napa Valley product and of stealing the grapes of another winery. His company has filed for bankruptcy and is being shut.
articles.lead_paragraph: When you buy a bottle of Napa Valley cabernet sauvignon, you trust that the bottle is filled with wine actually made from cabernet sauvignon grapes that were grown in the heart of California’s wine country.

articles.headline: A Quiet Revolution in Helping Lift the Burden of Student Debt
articles.snippet: Some little-noticed legislative changes have created conditions for a far-reaching overhaul of how a college education is bought and paid for.
articles.abstract: Some little-noticed legislative changes have created conditions for a far-reaching overhaul of how a college education is bought and paid for.
articles.lead_paragraph: Has the student loan crisis already been solved?

articles.headline: As Vatican Revisits Divorce, Many Catholics Long for Acceptance
articles.snippet: Pope Francis has begun a debate about the church’s treatment of divorced Catholics, and in October, a group of bishops will decide whether to recommend changes to him.
articles.abstract: Pope Francis has begun a debate about the church’s treatment of divorced Catholics, and in October, a group of bishops will decide whether to recommend changes to him.
articles.lead_paragraph: Mark Garren does not take communion when he goes to church. Sometimes he walks up to the priest, crosses his arms over his chest and touches his shoulders to signal that he is seeking a blessing. More often, mindful of his divorce years ago, Mr. Garren, a 64-year-old Illinoisan, remains in his pew, watching with slight embarrassment as the rest of the row moves to the front of the church.

articles.headline: North Korea’s Forbidden Love? Smuggled, Illegal Soap Operas
articles.snippet: Despite a crackdown on smugglers, South Korean soap operas are sneaking visions of a comfortable lifestyle into North Korea, causing some to defect.
articles.abstract: Despite a crackdown on smugglers, South Korean soap operas are sneaking visions of a comfortable lifestyle into North Korea, causing some to defect.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — As a math professor in North Korea, Jang Se-yul was among the nation’s relatively privileged classes; he got to sit in special seats in restaurants and on crowded trains, and more important in a country where many go hungry, was given priority for government food rations. Then he risked it all — for a soap opera from South Korea.

articles.headline: Republican Governors Buck Party Line on Raising Taxes
articles.snippet: There are proposals for raising the sales tax in Michigan, a tax on e-cigarettes in Utah and gas taxes in South Carolina and South Dakota, to name a few.
articles.abstract: There are proposals for raising the sales tax in Michigan, a tax on e-cigarettes in Utah and gas taxes in South Carolina and South Dakota, to name a few.
articles.lead_paragraph: Republican governors across the nation are proposing tax increases — and backing off pledges to cut taxes — as they strike a decidedly un-Republican pose in the face of budget shortfalls and pent-up demands from constituents after years of budget cuts.
articles.byline: By Adam Nagourney and Shaila Dewan

articles.headline: Greece Chooses Anti-Austerity Party in Major Shift
articles.snippet: Syriza’s victory, which positions Alexis Tsipras as prime minister, comes as Europe’s economic crisis has stirred populist anger.
articles.abstract: Syriza’s victory, which positions Alexis Tsipras as prime minister, comes as Europe’s economic crisis has stirred populist anger.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — Greece rejected the harsh economics of austerity on Sunday and sent a warning to the rest of Europe as the left-wing Syriza party won a decisive victory in national elections, positioning its tough-talking leader, Alexis Tsipras, to become the next prime minister.
articles.byline: By Jim Yardley and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Bloomberg Shakes Up Newsroom Side of His Company
articles.snippet: After his term as mayor ended, Michael Bloomberg has moved quickly to reassert control at the company that he founded and that bears his name, especially in its media operation.
articles.abstract: After his term as mayor ended, Michael Bloomberg has moved quickly to reassert control at the company that he founded and that bears his name, especially in its media operation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Things have changed at Bloomberg since its founder, Michael R. Bloomberg, returned to the office.

articles.headline: Unease for What Microsoft’s HoloLens Will Mean for Our Screen-Obsessed Lives
articles.snippet: Something about Microsoft’s new HoloLens technology feels unnerving, especially when considered against the dark television series “Black Mirror.”
articles.abstract: Something about Microsoft’s new HoloLens technology feels unnerving, especially when considered against the dark television series “Black Mirror.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Microsoft made a big announcement last week, revealing that Windows, a lucrative legacy franchise, was about to be unleashed into the physical environment through a set of goggles called the HoloLens that superimposes the operating system on the actual world. In one sense, it was heartening. Business reporters are frequently hung up on the new and the insurgent, but seeing mature companies adapt to a changed world is equally interesting.

articles.headline: Why Apps for Messaging Are Trending
articles.snippet: People are spending more time on messaging apps, which many say allow for multimedia exchanges and commerce in a more intimate setting than older social media sites.
articles.abstract: People are spending more time on messaging apps, which many say allow for multimedia exchanges and commerce in a more intimate setting than older social media sites.
articles.lead_paragraph: A team at BuzzFeed, the news and entertainment site, knew it had struck gold when it came across a decades-old photo of Dwayne Johnson, the musclebound wrestler and film star known as The Rock, wearing a fanny pack and dated bluejeans.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: Christie on Air: Undiluted and Pretty Great, if He Says So Himself
articles.snippet: A radio show featuring questions from the public provides an unfiltered picture of Chris Christie, the governor of New Jersey and would-be presidential candidate.
articles.abstract: A radio show featuring questions from the public provides an unfiltered picture of Chris Christie, the governor of New Jersey and would-be presidential candidate.
articles.lead_paragraph: EWING, N.J. — They call to complain about their pension payments, to grumble about their children’s teachers, to vent about the fine they just paid for stacking firewood incorrectly. They dial in by the thousands, from Toms River to Park Ridge, jamming the five phone lines here at the studio of WKXW-FM (101.5).

articles.headline: Catalogs, After Years of Decline, Are Revamped for Changing Times
articles.snippet: Retailers are still relying on direct mail, even as they spend resources on improving their websites to accommodate the increase of online shoppers.
articles.abstract: Retailers are still relying on direct mail, even as they spend resources on improving their websites to accommodate the increase of online shoppers.
articles.lead_paragraph: In this digital age when filling a shopping cart requires little more than clicking on a screen, the printed retail catalog keeps vying for a place on the coffee table.

articles.headline: Saudis Expand Regional Power as Others Falter
articles.snippet: Rather than undermine the Saudi dynasty, the chaos across the region after the Arab Spring revolts appears instead to have lifted the monarchy to unrivaled power and influence.
articles.abstract: Rather than undermine the Saudi dynasty, the chaos across the region after the Arab Spring revolts appears instead to have lifted the monarchy to unrivaled power and influence.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The rulers of Saudi Arabia trembled when the Arab Spring revolts broke out four years ago.

articles.headline: Middle Class Shrinks Further as More Fall Out Instead of Climbing Up
articles.snippet: Since 2000, the middle-class share of households has narrowed as more have fallen to the bottom of the economic ladder.
articles.abstract: Since 2000, the middle-class share of households has narrowed as more have fallen to the bottom of the economic ladder.
articles.lead_paragraph: The middle class that President Obama identified in his State of the Union speech last week as the foundation of the American economy has been shrinking for almost half a century.
articles.byline: By Dionne Searcey and Robert Gebeloff

articles.headline: A Drone, Too Small for Radar to Detect, Rattles the White House
articles.snippet: A system to detect flying objects failed to pick up a small drone, raising questions about whether the Secret Service could bring down a similar object if it endangered the president.
articles.abstract: A system to detect flying objects failed to pick up a small drone, raising questions about whether the Secret Service could bring down a similar object if it endangered the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A White House radar system designed to detect flying objects like planes, missiles and large drones failed to pick up a small drone that crashed into a tree on the South Lawn early Monday morning, according to law enforcement officials. The crash raised questions about whether the Secret Service could bring down a similar object if it endangered President Obama.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Michael D. Shear
